Steps to reproduce
------------------
Install multiple versions of powershell

Expected behavior
-----------------
The should be a common path where you can run the latest version of powershell.  Linux does this by creating a symbolic link.  We do it in the windows docker files by creating a symbolic link to the latest version.

Actual behavior
---------------
you have to figure out the latest version

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
Currently on Windows, you have to do something like:

```powershell
C:\> c:\pro<tab>\pow<tab>\6<tab>\powershell
```

And if you have multiple versions installed (which is currently the default), you have to tab through the older ones first (if you didn't uninstall them).  Would prefer something like:

```powershell
C:\> c:\pro<tab>\pow<tab>\l<tab>\powershell
```

We can even save typing `l` for latest by having it `.latest` to ensure it's first.

Another pain point is that powershell.exe is third file to be tab completed under it's version folder.  Perhaps what we really need is something like `set-defaultpowershell` which creates/updates a symlink that is in the user path so `win+r->powershell` starts it.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: We need to take into account that initially PowerShell 6 Core will coexist with Windows PowerShell. There may be a conflict with paths (to modules including).

comments.author: mirichmo
TravisEz13
comments.body: In docker containers, we are using `C:\program files\powershell\latest` as symbolic link to folder of the version we installed

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I agree that it should be `symbolic link to folder`.

title: The windows installer should create a common path you can run the latest powershell from
